title: Tahm Kench has a 37.4% winrate as a support and a 30.4% winrate as a top laner (Plat+)
body: Why are we still allowing new champions in ranked week one?

Except we're talking about low Win % as a focal point, because we've had first week release Champions that had high Win % and there's little argument against them. Use time as a factor only, because bringing Win % in means time is now irrelevant because now time as a factor now becomes COMPLETELY arbitrary.

Say a new Champ comes out, do we ban it for the first week then release it no matter what? Do we keep it banned if it's Win % goes up in Normals? When do you start taking into account their Win % in Ranked? If they dip back under X range do they get auto banned again for just being terrible Champions?

Either do it a flat time based (1st week ban) or don't do a ban at all, which... really... there's no reason there should be a ban on new Champions at all. If players wish to take a brand new Champion they have little to no experience into Ranked that's their prerogative, it's part of how the game (and competitive games in general) work.

But don't try and bring Win % in as a factor that really means anything because we've seen both sides.

Honestly whats the difference between playing a newly released champ in ranked and someone just trying a champ he doesn't know how to even play in ranked? For example I never played Annie in my life, so if I pick her, nobody would give a shit. But a tahm kench... Everybody on my team goes apeshit and bullies me, when I'm actually better at tk than Annie.

The thing is Annie's kit is pretty simple: Point and Click, a Cone, a Magic/Armor Booster and a Point and Click AoE. Only things you need to learn in the match are managing your passive and learning how much each spell does.

Tahm Kench meanwhile is managing your passive, deciding if and when to shield, swallowing the right target, ulting efficiently, among other things I can't think of because I haven't actually played him. The first week of release, people seem to think that everyone playing the champion either doesn't know what they are doing or opts for a troll build when some people learned after the first two or three games. Don't worry, the stigma will pass (except for poor {{champion:432}} ...)
